project.teaser: For space missions both Photovoltaic (PV) cells and Radioisotope Thermoelectrical Generators (RTG), fueled by Plutonium 238 (Pu-238) are used to produce electricity to power missions. From a European point of view, this has several drawbacks, as neither Pu-238 or any RTGs are...
project.objective:
For space missions both Photovoltaic (PV) cells and Radioisotope Thermoelectrical Generators (RTG), fueled by Plutonium 238 (Pu-238) are used to produce electricity to power missions. From a European point of view, this has several drawbacks, as neither Pu-238 or any RTGs are produced in Europe and RTGs are very power inefficient, with a yield often of 5% of the fuel potential. This means that large amounts of fuel, and large RTGs, are needed to power missions, which increases the payloads.
PULSAR is the first step on a European path to resolve these issues and take a world leading role in powering space exploration.
The PULSAR project has two overarching global ambitions. These are; • Develop, in Europe, the building blocks to establish the complete end-to-end capability to produce Pu-238 to help power existing Radioisotope Thermoelectric Generators (RTG) and Radioisotope Heater Units (RHUs) from the constituent elements to module production – addressing critical & non-dependencies technology needs; • Disruptively increase the thermo-electrical conversion efficiency of dynamic Radioisotope Power Systems (RPS) with an advanced Stirling engine improving the performance of the ”state-of-practice” thermoelectric materials.
This will be achieved by -Performing first designs and studies for selecting targets for Pu-238 generation, examine fabrication constraints and separation options -Designing a new welding methodology for iridium encapsulation by laser welding and produce a prototype capsule. -Designing and evaluating a robust Stirling convertor for use as an RPS -Addressing the regulatory and safety framework for Pu-238 use in space travel -Performing an analysis of the market potential and its segmentation for PULSAR results
PULSAR brings together a uniquely placed consortium led by TRACTEBEL, with the support of JRC, ESA and Ariane group.
project.title: PU-238-coupLed dynamic power system for SpAce exploRation and beyond
project.keywords: Plutonium 238 production, Radioisotope power system, Stirling engine, space exploration

article.title: Making power generation in space more efficient and affordable

result.title: Synthesis and characterisation of PuO2 pellets with representative microstructure.
result.description: The deliverable describes development of the Pu-238 pellet synthesis process and the characterisation results of the produced pellets with representative microstructure.

result.title: Shielding engineering
result.description: Assessment that the doses in some relevant locations due to the 238Pu radioactive source meet the safety criteria for the operators working in proximity of the RPS. If necessary, this is achieved by designing a shield.Estimation of the doses rates in the sensitive components. If the consequent lifetimes are too short, a shield will be defined (single material or multilayer) with the aim of achieving acceptable lifetimes of the components, respecting the weight constraints.

result.title: Boundary conditions for Np target fabrication
result.description: Investigation on the conversion routes with suitable chemical and physical properties for Np-237 target production.

result.title: Periodic Reporting for period 2 - PULSAR (PU-238-coupLed dynamic power system for SpAce exploRation and beyond)
result.teaser: Powering space exploration in regions where the sunlight is absent or insufficient requires the use of nuclear technologies. Today, Europe has a dependency on US, Russia and other external players to achieve its space exploration ambitions.Launched in the frame of...

result.title: Safety assessment, licensing and regulation
result.description: The deliverable will describe the results of the review and analysis of the existing safety documentation, as well as a roadmap for the required testing and safety analyses, and a description of the path forward towards future innovation according to the equivalent safety principle.
